data.title: Saving the Unhappy Kneecap Joint
authors: Nick Ilic Physio Clinician || The Tennis Physio
data.meta_description: Evidence-based management of Patellofemoral Pain (Kneecap pain)
data.text:
Itâ€™s a typical day at the clinic.

We typically treat the typical active population, who get the typical knee pain, which I had previously typically treated with typical interventions and exercises typically recommended by typical research.

â€¦well â€¦ until 2020 (the year when everything went haywire in the world) when I started treating typical knee pain, atypically.

Hereâ€™s the:

Typical Patellofemoral Pain Patient

The 20â€“40 active person comes in with tight knees and discomfort, perhaps an ache after working out, but it doesnâ€™t stop them. Itâ€™s getting worse or theyâ€™re fed up. Perhaps their knees are noisy.

This person has a history of having a week full of one or more of the following: jumping, squatting, running (especially with hills), or playing a sport with a variety of thoseâ€¦.they generally go â€œup and downâ€ a lot.

Thereâ€™s no history of direct trauma. Theyâ€™ve tried stretching, foam rolling, massage guns, trigger points any anything else that was recommended by their gym-going peers or their search on the internet but to no prevail.

They may or may not have had received the usual â€œadviceâ€ that: â€œnoisy knees means cartilage damageâ€ â€œtheir patella is mistrackingâ€ or â€œmaltrackingâ€, â€œthey have a weak VMO and/or a tight ITBâ€.

They may or may not have XR/MR imaging that reports â€œwear and tear/degeneration/osteoarthritic changesâ€.

On physical assessment thereâ€™s no deformities/abnormalities, they move normally, their foot posture is not outrageous â€” they are not â€œrolling inâ€ significantly.

Thereâ€™s mild to moderate pain with hopping, jumping and big step ups.

Thereâ€™s mild to moderate pain with (usually 50â€“80%) isometric knee extension strength (basically kicking their leg up against an immovable object).

They have full knee range of motion, no pain along the joint line of their tibiofemoral joint (aka â€˜The Main Knee Jointâ€), no history of instability, buckling or posterior knee pain.

On palpation (which is â€˜scienceâ€™ for: touching their bits) they usually have pain around the patella/kneecap.

Weâ€™ve ruled out (or donâ€™t yet suspect) the following: patella dysplasia, recent/acute patellofemoral instability episode (subluxation/dislocation), any other recent trauma such as landing on the kneecap area, patella tendinopathy (which is actually very uncommon outside of an elite sports environment, unless they are a regular jumper of some sort). We donâ€™t suspect fat pad involvement (also uncommon, but usually short-term if managed well) and weâ€™re fairly sure the tibiofemoral joint (main knee joint) isnâ€™t involved as thereâ€™s full range of motion there.

PAUSE THE SCENARIO!

What do you think? What do you tell them? What do you do to them? What do you recommend they do to themselves? What has the research told us over the past 20 years and how do we apply it?

That there, my friends, is the current challenge of Patellofemoral Pain (PFP), pain which refers from the Patellofemoral Joint (PFJ)

Runners Knee, Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome, Patella Mistracking Syndrome, Anterior knee Pain, Anterior Knee Pain Syndrome, Patella OuchyWouchy Syndromeâ€¦ whatever you call it, managing an overcooked patellofemoral joint (PFJ) is a challenge.

11â€“17% of knee pain presentations to GPs relate to PFP (Van Middelkoop, Van Linschoten, Berger, Koes, & Bierma-Zeinstra, 2008; Wood, Muller, & Peat, 2011), and in a sports clinic setting roughly 1/3 of knee pain cases relate to PFP (Kannus, Aho, JÃ¤rvinen, & NttymÃ¤ki, 1987; Taunton et al., 2002). When it comes to kids, 6â€“7% of the adolescents will get PFP (MÃ¸lgaard, Rathleff, & Simonsen, 2011; Michael Skovdal Rathleff, Roos, Olesen, & Rasmussen, 2015), but as will be outlined in this blogpost PFP occurs more often in active people, particularly those doing more jumping and â€˜vertical tasksâ€™ (hills/stairs), 16% of adolescent female basketballers for example (Myer et al., 2010).

Thereâ€™s a bit more going on than â€œTIGHT ITB and WEAK VMOâ€, which is â€œtHe CAuSe oF aLL KneE ISsUeS!?â€ according to those who arenâ€™t health professionals or those who are health professionals but lack the time to explain complex health conditions to patients and manage them well.

On a recent BJSM podcast it was raised as the â€œlow back pain of the lower limbâ€ as a statement on how little we still know about it and the challenges in managing PFP. There are so many potential nociceptive structures (things that can cause a nociceptive stimulus into the brain, the output of which is: pain) around the PFJ: Hoffas Fat pad, Patella tendon, Patella capsule, MPFL, VMO, ITB, Patella Bone, Tibial Tuberosity, Anterior Tibiofemoral joint referralâ€¦ and much more.

There has been a lot of interest in the management of PFP in the past 10 years. We are fresh off a decade-long â€˜bandwagonâ€™ of suspecting â€œtight ITBs and weak VMOsâ€ were causing a â€œpatella trackingâ€ issueâ€¦ before we realised that there was more pain-free and happy people with â€œpatella maltrackingâ€ on imaging than painful people, therefore it must be quite a normal variation (similar to the â€œankle/foot pronation is a villainâ€ narrative, which popular shoe stores still use to upsell expensive shoes).

After we tracked away from maltracking and â€œfoam rolling (or stretching) all the tight ITBsâ€ (which was implausible to begin with) we moved onto Gluteus Medius as primary driver of PFP, because it shares a role of lower limb stability to avoid knee valgus (have a drink every time â€˜valgusâ€™ comes up in this post, I dare you!). Glute medius being an active force (70%) to resist dynamic valgus, and ITB/TFL being a passive restraint (30%.. or so weâ€™re told).

I started to suspect there was more to managing this condition than the above, and that hunch was confirmed once I read an in-depth blog on this condition at the www.painscience.com/ website by Paul Ingraham which spelt out what is assumed now to be â€˜Fake Newsâ€™, or put more subtly, misinformation/misunderstanding of the research. A great chat between Dr Bradley Neal and Greg Lehman on episode 48 of The NAF Physio Podcast discussing patellofemoral pain and knee biomechanics highlighted that we simply donâ€™t know whatâ€™s cause and effect in the PFJ, particularly when it comes to hip adduction/knee valgus.

For me, management involving activity modification and education of this condition is crucial as patients can do as much foam rolling or stretching as they like however if they are still doing a high amount of â€˜up and downâ€™ activities in the week theyâ€™ll get nowhere.

Who is the Typical PFP Patient?

20â€“50 years of age

Fairly active throughout the week â€” likes to run, jump, hop, do gym glasses, do weights, play sports.

Has Anterior (front of) knee pain

For the purposes of keeping this blog as short as possible, the following needs to be also considered however letâ€™s assume the above â€˜Typical Patientâ€™ doesnâ€™t have them:

A recent history of instability (subluxation/dislocation)

A recent history of landing on the kneecap (contusion)

Localised patella tendon pain (should be a regular athletic jumper if they do)

Patella Dysplasia (including patella and trochlea dysplasia and patella alta etc)

Younger pathology such as an active Osgood Schlatters/tibial tuberosity apophysitis pain

The PatelloFemoral Joint

Oh boy, this is a beautiful joint. I donâ€™t know why I like it so much, itâ€™s justâ€¦ odd and complexâ€¦yet simple.

The role of the PFJ is to hold you up (stop the knee from buckling) by producing a knee extension force. Knee extension is pivotal in kicking and jumping sports and is especially challenged by up/down tasks such as incline running, heavy squats and jumping.

The key components of the PatelloFemoral Joint are:

The Patella bone and the Femoral boneâ€¦thus â€˜patellofemoralâ€™ (â€¦.. get it? these science boffins sometimes good at naming stuff!)

The Patella (Patello-)

..is a floating bone suspended inside a tendon (quadriceps tendon), thereâ€™s even some fibres that are continuous through the bone which is amazing. It has two facets (flat surfaces), a medial facet (toward the body midline) and a lateral facet (away from the body midline). The lateral facet tends to take more load and demonstrate degenerative changes earlier in active people. The facets are covered in articular cartilage which help protect the bone of the patella. The patella, if viewed from above (caudal view) resembles a triangle, which fits nicely in the triangle groove of the Femoral Trochlea. This â€˜nice fitâ€™ is called â€˜joint congruencyâ€™ and itâ€™s really important for happy joints that are put under load regularly. This lovely colourful pic gives a nice representation of â€˜spread of joint surface interactionâ€™, which I discuss later.

The Femur (-femoral)

..is the distal or far end of the biggest bone in the body forms the top part of the knee complex. The patella fits nicely in a groove called the â€˜Femoral Trochlear Grooveâ€™, which sits between the two big ball shaped bits called the â€˜Condylesâ€™. As the colourful picture shows, the Patella glides up and down the Trochlear Groove depending on the position of the knee (different degrees of flexion). As weâ€™ll find out later, the better the fit (joint congruency) of the patella into that groove and the more the two surface areas remain in touch the more comfortable patients with PFP are (in the absence of trauma and focal articular cartilage loss).

Thereâ€™s a joint capsule (shown in blue above). Thereâ€™s not much chat about joint capsules but they might be one a contributor to nociception around the PFJ.

Finally, thereâ€™s a whole bunch of soft-tissues and ligaments which help stabilise the patella in the PFJ. Including the medial retinaculum MPFL (medial patellofemoral ligament, usually torn or ruptured during PFJ instability episodes) and the infamous VMO and VL/ITB complex.

What does the PFJ do? What Loads it?

Apart from holding you up when youâ€™re upright and stopping your knee from buckling under your body weight, as a part of the quadriceps-knee extension complex, the PFJ helps you go â€˜up and down stuffâ€™.

A recent study (Hart et al., 2022) gives some does data on what loads the PFJ. This is shown in my graph adapted form the study below.

The more force (or massâ€¦ or acceleration â€¦.. yesâ€¦. F=MA) the more the PFJ load.

The Hart study suggests that the PFJ is loaded with tasks that

1. Have a high quads demand, and

2. Are in deeper knee flexion

The Pain

I have previous discussed the hip joint and how we often get â€˜join referred painâ€™ into common but vague areas. The PFJ is similar in that it is often extremely difficult to be specific about what is causing the pain. However there are some studies which have a crack:

A 2011 paper (Farrokhi, Keyak, & Powers, 2011) creatively and fortunately titled â€œindividuals with patellofemoral pin exhibit greater patellofemoral joint stressâ€ surprisingly found that â€¦ (wait for it) individuals with patellofemoral pain exhibit greater patellofemoral joint stress!

However, â€¦ itâ€™s chicken or the eggâ€¦. Does pain change the way people move and function, or does the way people move and function change the pain? So what causes the pain? These authors suggest the increased hydrostatic pressure of the joint fluid could stir up the bone-cartilage (osteochondral) interface.

Two Docs do something Dodgy

Letâ€™s probe further into what could cause pain in the knee by talking about one very cool study (albeit n=1 study) (Dye, Vaupel, & Dye, 1998)that might not pass an ethic committee today.

A Surgeon and his Mate (also a surgeon) were sitting around drinking one night when he said to his mate:

â€œHey! What if you cut open (arthroscope) both of my knees and poke (with a spring loaded device with a 3mm tip) and all around the knee and kneecap joints (with 300â€“500g of pressure) and see what hurts and what doesnâ€™t!â€

To which his mate said:

â€œShit yes! Letâ€™s do that!â€

(Legal disclaimer: This conversation may or may not have happened this way, I just like to think it did)

So a 46yo Dr Scott Dye had both his knees scoped by his mate Dr Geoff Vaupel and they poked all around the joint and this is what they found to be painful (scale 0: nothing, 4: very ouchy):

This is the sort of stuff that deserves a Nobel Prize ala Australian Dr Barry Marshal winning a Nobel Prize for swallowing gastic ulcer-causing Helicobacter Pylori bacteria.

For the past several years I was thinking that a distension of the joint capsule due to increased fluid inside the PFJ may contribute to that vague feeling of â€œtightnessâ€ around the joint, however Iâ€™ve recently pulled back from that idea in favour of the feeling of tightness and other symptoms being a â€˜non-specific joint referralâ€™, Iâ€™ve written more about â€˜Non-Specific Joint Referralsâ€™ here.

Self-Limiting

Unlike the tibiofemoral joint (or the â€œmain knee jointâ€), the PFP is â€œself-limitingâ€ in that it resolves over time, and those who have it can (and do) push through a fair bit of discomfort and it often doesnâ€™t stop them doing tasks until it gets really stirred up.

However, just because it doesnâ€™t stop the patients doesnâ€™t mean they arenâ€™t affected. A 2 year follow up of adolescents with PFP found that a quarter of them had PFP over that 2 years and it affected their performance in sports and also their quality of life (Michael S Rathleff, Rathleff, Olesen, Rasmussen, & Roos, 2016). Clinically, we see many adults in their 20s and 30s who suffer have suffered from PFP for years, many report they arrive reporting a â€œlifelong disabilityâ€ affecting their knees making stairs/jumping/squats activities very uncomfortable (at best) and painful (at worst). Fortunately the majority of these have simply been mismanaged (ITB stretches and isolated VMO exercises probably) and have potential to settle.

Some patients have developed a irrational fear about the sounds and feelings around their knees, especially the Crunchy or Clicky knee:

The Crunchy Knee â€” Patellofemoral Creptius

The Wonderful Claire Robertson, aka â€˜Claire Patellaâ€™ who is a UK Physiotherapist has some fantastic resources on Cracking or Crunchy knees which we call â€˜Crepitusâ€™.

The summary is, you can have noisy knees without pain, you can have quiet knees with pain and you can be anywhere in between, but you shouldnâ€™t let your noisy â€˜crunchyâ€™ knees worry you if you are active and not getting too much Patellofemoral Pain, itâ€™s not necessarily a sign of joint damage. See an experienced registered healthcare professional for assessment if you have concerns.

For more on this, here is a nice blog on Tom Goomâ€™s (Running-physio.com) webpage by Clare: https://www.running-physio.com/crepitus/

What have we been doing about it the last 20 years

Patella â€œMaltrackingâ€

A quick search on google will suggest you have a â€œtight ITBâ€ and/or a â€œweak VMOâ€ which may be causing â€œpatella maltrackingâ€ and you need to â€œlengthen your ITBâ€ with foam rolling or deep tissue massage and â€œstrengthen your VMOâ€ with VMO exercises.

You can use â€˜McConnell Tapingâ€™ to pull the kneecap back across so itâ€™s â€˜in alignmentâ€™ (*SHUDDER*.. I hate that word). However, there may be some other reasons why McConnellâ€™s taping works and it has nothing to do with pulling it mediallyâ€¦ but more to do with compressing the patella back into the groove, or getting as much of the two joint surfaces in touch with each other, Mike Reinold has a nice blog on that here.

All of the above â€œPatella Maltracking from tight ITB and weak VMOâ€ is simply an outdated concept (for insidious onset PFP in the absence of trauma and instability) and yes even I was doing this â€˜patella maltrackingâ€™ stuff back in the mid 2010s. Everyone was on a foam roller and doing isolated VMO exercises in my clinic. Fortunately Iâ€™ve unlearned and evolved as a Clinician.

So is it just quads weakness then?

So if it isnâ€™t VMO it must just be weakness of the Knee Extensors (quads) as a group that causes PFP, thatâ€™s just commons sense right?

Perhaps.

For a while there I was testing knee extension â€œstrengthâ€ of my PFP patients and if the affected knee was weaker Iâ€™d say:

â€œAH HA! Weak Quads, thatâ€™s why you have PFP!â€

But then one must consider two words, which can be simplified into four words.

Arthrogenic Inhibition, â€¦..or â€œOUCHY JOINT, WEAKY MUSCLEâ€

â€˜Arthrâ€™ = joint, â€˜genicâ€™ = from there, â€˜inhibitionâ€™ = unable to work normallyâ€¦ so the joint is causing nearby things not work normally.

5 years ago I would have said the majority of PFP patients I saw had weak quads causing PFP, but now I say the majority have PFP causing weak quads, and if we reduce PFP via other means we donâ€™t increase the strength of the knee extensors, we DIS-inhibit themâ€¦ we just allow them to work normally.

There are still some less common 1-in 50â€“100ish cases (in my clinical experience) that have a knee extension weakness causing PFP, interestingly these are often knee extension weakness secondary to other conditions that are lumbar spine or hip joint based.

Planes and Interventions

Another way to look the last 10â€“20 years of patellofemoral management is to visualise the interventions and how what forces they apply to the patella in terms of whether it is Sagittal Plane or Frontal Plane forces.

The bread and butter of the PFP management up until around 2010â€“2015 was focused on â€œpatella trackingâ€ and avoiding a lateral patellar force, best achieved by taping (direction doesnâ€™t matter), VMO strengthening (canâ€™t isolate it) and ITB rolling (to â€œlengthen itâ€ â€” virtually impossible).

Since then the value of â€˜sucking the kneecap into the grooveâ€™ with a sagital plane-compression force via quads â€˜strengtheningâ€™/knee extension force production, and taping to hold the kneecap in the groove (sagital) rather than pulling it to the side (frontal) seems to have a higher value in keeping the kneecap joint happy.

Another proposed contributer to â€˜adverseâ€™ sagittal front plane patellar forces is dynamic and forceful â€˜Valgusâ€™.

Gluteus Medius and the Battle against Valgus

Hip joint adduction and internal rotation movement during running, squatting and stair tasks is suggested to increase compressive loads at the PFJ, allegedly due to â€œpoor gluteal functionâ€.

However, this concept was founded from one study that focused on young female runners and the results werenâ€™t that conclusive (Powers, 2010), further studies have shown only short-term effects only from targeting hip abductors/lateral rotators with â€˜strengthâ€™ exercises (Fukuda et al., 2012) and recent reviews have even reported a lack of hip strength isnâ€™t even predictive of developing PFP (Michael Skovdal Rathleff, Rathleff, Crossley, & Barton, 2014).

So does Hip Abductor weakness lead to pain? Or does pain lead to weakness (ie â€˜Inhibitionâ€™) and hip muscle strength isnâ€™t the magic bullet to target PFP (Thijs, Pattyn, Van Tiggelen, Rombaut, & Witvrouw, 2011).

To further debunk the â€œyou only need to target posterolateral hip muscles for PFP reductionâ€ concept a crafty and high quality study randomised 52 women with PFP into:

A posterolateral hip strength group (the traditional abductors and external rotators) and,

The other group did the complete opposite, anteromedial hip strength (adductors and internal rotators)

â€¦.and guess what?! They found that both groups showed improvement and there was no difference between the groups (Almeida, das Neves Rodrigues, Coelho, Rodrigues, & de Paula Lima, 2021).

So in summary, there is benefit to providing Hip Strength exercises for Patellofemoral pain and it doesnâ€™t have to be specific.

The Consensus

The 2016 Patellofemoral pain consensus statement from the 4th International Patellofemoral Pain Research Retreat (Crossley et al., 2016) and more recently a living (â€¦. on the living.. not the dead) systematic review with network meta-analysis (Winters et al., 2021) found that the most effective treatment for PFP is a combination of :

1. Education

2. Exercise (hip-based and knee-based)

3. Patellar Taping (Winters et al. included Patella Mobilisation here, Crossley et al. didnâ€™t recommend it), and

4. Foot Orthoses (off the shelf).

One big thing missing here in my opinion: education and activity modification, which in my experience has been crucial. Even though they mention â€˜educationâ€™ I dug deeper into the Winters et al 2021 article in a previous blogpost and I found that their source for â€˜educationâ€™.

The education was focused on the valgus knee-postures with activities, so presumably patients can continue doing everything with less valgus? In other words, â€˜internal loadsâ€™ (postures, weaknesses, flexibility, joint tracking) are the focus and â€˜external loadsâ€™ (activities, load) are lost in the noiseâ€.

Even though the â€œeducationâ€ in the above bar graph is low in effective management, sometimes education and activity modificaiton (dialling back up & downs) is all I do and they still get better.

My Thoughts

PFJ Referral Patterns

Most PFP I see refers around the medial side of the patella (90% of patellofemoral patients), but some get lateral sided pain (lateral to the patella, not the tibiofemoral joint). I often find that the lateral sided patellofemoral pain are the patients whoâ€™ve had a history of trauma such as PFJ instability (subluxation/dislocation) or at the other end of the spectrum they are the â€œvery gradual loadersâ€ (eg: long-distance runners) whoâ€™ve hit a physiological ceiling in joint metabolism (the joint simply canâ€™t take another kilometre on an inclined treadmill on the 45year old knee). However, PFP can refer anywhere around the kneecap.

Patella Tendinopathy.. or is it?

I get itâ€¦ everyone wants a cool Tendinopathy to rehab. We spend hours learning about them on weekend Sports Rehab courses. However, true Patella Tendinopathy is rare in the main active population.

Unfortunately, many â€œPatella Tendinopathyâ€ second opinions walk into my clinic and ask me for my thoughts and assessment for their â€œJumpers Kneeâ€ or â€œPatella Tendinopathyâ€ and the first thing I ask is â€œare you a professional jumper?â€ (volleyball, basketball) or ask if they do anything hard and fast change-of-direction tasksâ€¦ usually not.

Usually these â€œpatella tendonâ€ patients are in fact inferior referring PFJs. Superiorly referring PFJs cause a feeling of â€œtightnessâ€ in the distal quadriceps area (just superior to the PFJ), I have seen patients for second opinions who have been prescribed stretches for this â€œtightnessâ€, of course, to no effect.

What if it isnâ€™t the knee?

Every knee pain patient, especially those with longer term pain, should get their hip joints cleared for hip joint referred pain, which can refer into the thigh, the ITB area and the anterior knee (and as far as the foot).

This will typically present as a deep, vague, and difficult to find ache in the area. I had it once, it felt like I had been â€œtapped on the ballsâ€, a very mild kick in the nuts, but in my knee. (Testicular pain, for those grown-ups who had no idea what I was talking about).

Hip joints are very easy to rule out (or consider as less likely). Perform a FADIR test. Any patient with even a mildly cranky hip joint will get stirred up.

Finally, I had once case where persistent patellofemoral knee pain (with a marked weakness of the quads) was from a L3 spinal nerve root stenosis/impingement. Clear the lumbar spine in long-term cases.

My Abandoned â€˜Effusion Model of Painâ€™

I used to think much of the patellofemoral pain I saw in the clinic was related to a PFJ effusion as a result of a load to an underconditioned joint surface that leads to â€˜leakingâ€™, 24â€“48hrs after loading.

Iâ€™d educate the patient on â€˜Conditioningâ€™ using a metaphor of â€˜blister vs callousâ€™ and how we want to callous up the joint surface with gradual loading so it can tolerate load and avoid too much too son otherwise weâ€™ll get a â€˜blisterâ€™ and get too much fluid.

Iâ€™d hypothesise that the Joint Capsule of the PFP would get distended with an effusion and as it is highly innervated this would be the cause of the majority of the PFP. This was a nice narrative for both myself (clinician) and my patients, it helped explain the distribution of the symptoms and also made sense with management (more fluid out vs more fluid in), but itâ€™s not exactly correct.

Non-Specific Joint Pain

More often than not we actually may not know what exact structure inside the PFJ is causing pain, thus the non-specific diagnosis of â€œPatellofemoral Painâ€ (+ syndromeâ€¦.).

This is what I now give to patients to explain their PFP.

Essentially, I tell them, â€œyou have a cranky knee-cap joint and you are getting knee-cap joint referred pain and/or tightness, what exactly is causing the pain we* donâ€™t know, however it doesnâ€™t change the initial managementâ€

*weâ€¦ as in the â€˜Medical Worldâ€™ or the â€˜Research Worldâ€™â€¦. I like to share the blameâ€¦as well as the credit. ğŸ˜Š

Education and Activity Modification

It is vital that the patient fully understands what loads the joint and exercise they can continue without stirring it up further.

There has been too much focus on correcting â€˜internal loadâ€™ (tissue tightness, joint maltracking) and targeting interventions to that (exercise therapy) and not enough attention on â€˜external loadâ€™ or what the patient has done to themselves, with advice and education on load management/activity modification (M. Rathleff, 2016). This problem of focusing solely on managing â€˜internal loadâ€™ isnâ€™t unique to PFP, it has been to focus of treatment of low back pain (core stability, flexibility, foot/ankle overpronation) and also other tricky conditions such as Tennis Elbow for decades. Not only does this focus ignore what the patient is doing to themselves throughout the week, but it also sells a narrative of the patient being â€œfragileâ€ (weak) or â€œdeformedâ€ (tightness).

External Load â€” Managing the Ups and the Downs

I spend a good chunk of the initial assessment with PFP patients identifying all the â€˜up and downsâ€™ in their life.

Unless the PFP is particularly bad (see below for what I class as bad) I encourage the patient to continue all physical activities that are relatively flat, whilst temporarily reducing â€˜up and downâ€™ activities (particularly jumping and incline/decline tasks).

My Assessment

I have some main assessment items that I track with PFP patients.

Isolated PFP that is mild-moderate may have no loss of pain-free range of motion (ROM), the cranky PFP knees will often get 0â€“100 without any issues before a broad anterior knee â€œtightnessâ€ or pain.

Apart from functional items (pain with walk, squat, run, hop and jump) I pay particularly attention the following:

1. Up/Down Assessment â€” Steps â†’ Hopping

Stepping up on a small step (20â€“30cm), and if pain-free stepping up on a standard bench or chair (50cm), and seeing if there is pain. If there is no pain, I will then do a Step Down test, where they step down from a bench with their GOOD foot, leaving the knee with anterior knee pain behind. In my clinical experience I find that if a patient can produce 80% pain-free knee extension force compared with their good knee they can complete this test pain-free.

2. Pain-free Knee Extension Force (PF-KEF)

I measure the patients pain-free knee extension force at 20deg flexion (supine with foam roller under knee) and 90deg flexion (sitting on side of bed) in a â€˜makeâ€™ isometric test (holding a handheld dynamometer still and getting them to â€œpush into me as hard as is comfortable or until you feel painâ€. If I have a high-needs patient (aka Athletic) Iâ€™ll also measure PF-KEF at 60deg knee flexion. The research-boffins suggest that an isometric test is valid 20deg in either direction so 20 is 0â€“40, 60 is 40â€“80, and 90 is 70â€“110), but I think that is a rough guide and not set in stone.

I record the results as a % averaged across the testing positions

Eg: Left knee painful, Right knee good.

L/R PF-KEF20: 40/50 (80%)

L/R PF-KEF90: 30/40 (75%)

75+80/2 = 77.5%

Yes, ideally if I had all the dollar$ Iâ€™d have an isokinetic dynamometer, however I donâ€™t have all the dollar$ so Iâ€™ll make do with a not-as-valid-yet-good-enough-but-still-very-expensive handheld dynamometer.

What sort of values am I looking in the patient depends on whether theyâ€™re athletic or not-athletic, and it also depends on their body weight. Here is a very rough guide to some normative values based on my experience :

Whatâ€™s nice about the table above is thereâ€™s too variables you can play with. You can increase force production or the patient can lose weight.

Here is my rough guide for how to proceed based on the assessment, using the difference of PF-KEF between affected and unaffected side:

Whatâ€™s great with the above table is that â€˜up/down assessmentâ€™ can be done via telehealth/online consults.. or even given as a guide to patients to help them self-manage and make good decisions about sports/exercise on a week by week basis.

Over time as their PF-KEF improves Iâ€™ll gradually bring in more and more â€˜up and downâ€™ tasks depending on whatever it is the patient is getting back to.

Rehab â€” Hip and Knee Interventions

As mentioned above, the current consensus is that prescription of BOTH hip and knee based resistance exercises are effective in the management of Patellofemoral pain.

We have one study that showed that this doesnâ€™t have to be specific around the hip, so fill your boots with your favourite hip exercises (eg: glutes), however for knee based exercises I would add the following, particularly in the rare situation when there is a knee extension weakness contributing to ongoing PFP.

For the patient in front of you, test out different â€œquads strengthâ€ exercises and find 2â€“3 that makes the patient feel it in their quads, not their knee.
